info.name: Naurt v1
info.description:
This is a Postman collection for the Naurt API endpoints. Please refer to the main [Naurt API documentation](https://docs.naurt.com/) for more details.

### Quick install

Go to the [Collection](https://www.postman.com/team-naurt/workspace/naurt-apis/collection/36617726-d48519fc-966a-449a-8f2a-f7e0b02a8dc3) and click `Run in Postman`.

All requests have detailed examples with them along with the them, which can help in understand the usage better.

### Manual install

You can also download this Collection from GitHub repo here: [Github](https://github.com/Naurt-Ltd-Public/final-destination-examples)

## Environment

This Collection includes a pre-configured Environment. The Pre-requisite script in the Final Destination folder will set the final destination url for all requests. User may have to run a request twice for the very first time to get the variable set. Subsequently it will be takken automatically.

item.name: Final Destination
Geocoding API

request.description:
Geocoding is the process of encoding an address into a latitude & longitude coordinate. With Naurt, this takes on a slightly different form. Instead of responding with a single coordinate, Naurt will respond with a [GeoJSON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GeoJSON) containing the building's entrances, parking zones, and outline.

## [Request](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/geocode#request)

Naurt data can be searched via a `POST` request to the **final-destination endpoint**. Again, data should be provided as a JSON in the body of the request and not in the URL.

``` json
{
  "address_string": Optional<String>, 
  "country": Optional<String>,
  "latitude": Optional<Float>,
  "longitude": Optional<Float>,
  "distance_filter": Optional<Float>,
  "additional_matches": Optional<Bool>,
}

 ```

response.name: Get door and parking details for search by address
Get door and parking details addrress with country
Get additional door and parking spots
Get door and parking details with address and geolocation
Get door and parking details with distance filter

body.raw:
{
    "address_string": "9, Cornfield Terrace, Eastbourne, East Sussex, BN21 4NN",
    "latitude": 50.765867,
    "longitude": 0.28506,
    "additional_matches": true,
    "distance_filter": 7000,
    "country": "UK"
}

item.description:
Geocoding is the process of encoding an address into a latitude & longitude coordinate. With Naurt, this takes on a slightly different form. Instead of responding with a single coordinate, Naurt will respond with a [GeoJSON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GeoJSON) containing the building's entrances, parking zones, and outline.

## [Request](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/geocode#request)

Naurt data can be searched via a `POST` request to the **final-destination endpoint**. Again, data should be provided as a JSON in the body of the request and not in the URL.

``` json
{
  "address_string": Optional<String>, 
  "country": Optional<String>,
  "latitude": Optional<Float>,
  "longitude": Optional<Float>,
  "distance_filter": Optional<Float>,
  "additional_matches": Optional<Bool>,
}

 ```

### [Parameters](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/geocode#parameters)

| Parameter | Type | Optional | Default | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **latitude** | float | Yes | None | A valid latitude in [WGS84](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Geodetic_System#WGS_84) degrees. Range: -90 <= lat <= 90. |
| **longitude** | float | Yes | None | A valid longitude in [WGS84](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Geodetic_System#WGS_84) degrees. Range: -180 <= lon < 180. |
| **distance_filter** | float | Yes | 5000 | A distance in metres (larger than 0) within which you wish to search for POIs. When a filter is applied a latitude and longitude must also be provided. Maximum value of 25000 metres. |
| **address_string** | String | Yes | None | An address string. Good formatting, spelling, and completeness will offer the best search results. |
| **additional_matches** | Boolean | Yes | False | Provides up to 4 results beyond what Naurt classifies as the `best_match`. |
| **country** | String | Yes | None | Optional but strongly suggested two digit country code which helps with performance. |

## [Response](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/geocode#response)

### [Success](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/geocode#success)

A `200` response code indicates a successful response with the format as follows.

``` json
{
  "best_match": Optional<DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT>,
  "additional_matches": Optional<List<DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT>>,
  "version": Optional<String>
}

 ```

Naurt will identify the single best match for you. You will only have an `additional_matches` field if you set `additional_matches` to true in the request.

The `DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT` is

``` json
{
  "id": String,
  "address": String,
  "geojson": GeoJSON,
  "distance": Optional<float>
}

 ```

- Note that the `address` field is the normalised address and may not match the address you searched with.
    
- Distance will only be present if you search with a `latitude` and `longitude` and will be the distance of the destination from that position in metres.
    

### [Failure](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/geocode#failure)

A response code other than `200` indicates a failure to retrieve the requested destination.

401 Unauthorized

``` json
{"error":"Please ensure the request contains a valid API key."}

 ```

If there are no destinations available which match the search term, the response JSON will not contain any results, but instead a "naurt_info" message.

``` json
{"naurt_info":"Successful request. No destinations match search conditions."}

 ```

item.name: Reverse Geocoding

request.description:
Naurt data can be reverse-searched via a `POST` request to the **final-destination endpoint**. Again, data should be provided as a JSON in the body of the request and not in the URL.

``` json
POST  https://api.naurt.net/final-destination/v1
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: <API_KEY_HERE>
{
  "latitude": Optional<Float>,
  "longitude": Optional<Float>,
  "country": Optional<String>,
  "distance_filter": Optional<Float>,
  "additional_matches": Optional<Bool>,
}

 ```

response.name: Get door and parking details with lat/lon
Get door and parking details with lat/lon and country
Get additional door and parking details with lat/lon
Get door and parking details with lat/lon and address
Get door and parking details with distance filter

item.description:
Reverse geocoding is the process of finding addresses near a latitude & longitude. Naurt provides this functionality, but once again returns [GeoJSON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GeoJSON) parking zones, building entrances, and building outlines.

## [Request](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/reverse-geocode#request)

Naurt data can be reverse-searched via a `POST` request to the **final-destination endpoint**. Again, data should be provided as a JSON in the body of the request and not in the URL.

``` json
POST  https://api.naurt.net/final-destination/v1
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: <API_KEY_HERE>
{
  "latitude": Optional<Float>,
  "longitude": Optional<Float>,
  "country": Optional<String>,
  "distance_filter": Optional<Float>,
  "additional_matches": Optional<Bool>,
}

 ```

### [Parameters](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/reverse-geocode#parameters)

| Parameter | Type | Optional | Default | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **latitude** | float | Yes | None | A valid latitude in [WGS84](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Geodetic_System#WGS_84) degrees. Range: -90 <= lat <= 90. |
| **longitude** | float | Yes | None | A valid longitude in [WGS84](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Geodetic_System#WGS_84) degrees. Range: -180 <= lon < 180. |
| **distance_filter** | float | Yes | 5000 | A distance in metres (larger than 0) within which you wish to search. When a filter is applied a latitude and longitude must also be provided. Maximum value of 25000 metres |
| **additional_matches** | Boolean | Yes | False | Provides up to 4 results beyond what Naurt classifies as the `best_match`. |
| **country** | String | Yes | None | Optional but strongly suggested two digit country code which helps with performance. |

## [Response](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/reverse-geocode#response)

### [Success](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/reverse-geocode#success)

A `200` response code indicates a successful response with the format as follows.

``` json
{
  "best_match": Optional<DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT>,
  "additional_matches": Optional<List<DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT>>,
  "version": Optional<String>
}

 ```

Naurt's best match will be the closest destination to the requested location. You will only have an `additional_matches` field if you set `additional_matches` to true in the request.

The `DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT` is

``` json
{
  "id": String,
  "address": String,
  "geojson": GeoJSON,
  "distance": Optional<float>
}

 ```

Distance will only be present if you search with a `latitude` and `longitude` and will be the distance of the destination from that position in metres.

### [Failure](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/reverse-geocode#failure)

A response code other than `200` indicates a failure to retrieve the requested destination.

``` json
401 Unauthorized 
{"error":"Please ensure the request contains a valid API key."}

 ```

If there are no destinations available which match the search term, the response JSON will not contain any results, but instead a "naurt_info" message.

``` json
{"naurt_info":"Successful request. No destinations match search conditions."}

 ```

## [Search Restrictions](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/reverse-geocode#search-restrictions)

Destinations requested via the API are subject to some restrictions.

- No more than 300 requests per minute can be sent to this endpoint per API key. This limit can be adjusted by speaking to our [support team](https://www.naurt.com/contact).
    
- Currently there is a maximum return of 5 destinations per request.
    

To limit the search to a specific radius, you can apply a `distance_filter` up to a maximum of 25000m. If unused, it defaults to 5000m.

item.name: Search By Id

request.description:
You may have noticed that every destination comes with an `id` field. This is a unique ID for every address. You can also search by this. You could, for example, keep a list of favourite addresses.

## [Request](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/search-by-id#request)

``` json
POST  https://api.naurt.net/final-destination/v1
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: <API_KEY_HERE>
{
  "id": Optional<String>, 
  "country": Optional<String>
}

 ```

response.name: Get door and parking details by known unique id

item.description:
You may have noticed that every destination comes with an `id` field. This is a unique ID for every address. You can also search by this. You could, for example, keep a list of favourite addresses.

## [Request](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/search-by-id#request)

``` json
POST  https://api.naurt.net/final-destination/v1
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: <API_KEY_HERE>
{
  "id": Optional<String>, 
  "country": Optional<String>
}

 ```

### [Parameters](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/search-by-id#parameters)

| Parameter | Type | Optional | Default | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **id** | String (UUID) | Yes | None | The unique address ID for direct lookup. |
| **country** | String | Yes | None | Optional but strongly suggested two digit country code which helps with performance. |

## [Response](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/search-by-id#response)

### [Success](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/search-by-id#success)

A `200` response code indicates a successful response with the format as follows.

``` json
{
  "best_match": Optional<DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT>,
  "version": Optional<String>
}

 ```

The `best_match` in this case will be the matching ID.

The `DESTINATION RESPONSE FORMAT` is

``` json
{
  "id": String,
  "address": String,
  "geojson": GeoJSON
}

 ```

### [Failure](https://docs.naurt.com/final-destination/search-by-id#failure)

A response code other than `200` indicates a failure to retrieve the requested destination.

``` json
401 Unauthorized 
{"error":"Please ensure the request contains a valid API key."}

 ```

In the case that no matching ID can be found, the response JSON will not contain any results, but instead a "naurt_info" message.

``` json
{"naurt_info":"Successful request. No destinations match search conditions."}

 ```

item.name: GeoJson Visualizer

request.description:
# Echo visualizer

Requests showing how you can use the Postman Visualizer - by sending the data you want to visualize to the Postman Echo API.

- The [Postman Echo API](https://docs.postman-echo.com/) helps you learn Postman by echoing back whatever you send it.
    
- This template uses a `POST` request with **raw** `JSON` in the **Body** to send the data you want to visualize. Here we are using the [Naurt](https://www.naurt.com/) GeoJSON [responses](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/geocoding#responses) data.
    
- Check out the **Body** of the request to access and change the visualization data.
    
- Open the request scripts tab to see how Postman builds the response data into a visualization. Change it to tweak your display!

# Echo visualizer

Requests showing how you can use the Postman Visualizer - by sending the data you want to visualize to the Postman Echo API.

- The [Postman Echo API](https://docs.postman-echo.com/) helps you learn Postman by echoing back whatever you send it.
    
- This template uses a `POST` request with **raw** `JSON` in the **Body** to send the data you want to visualize. Here we are using the [Naurt](https://www.naurt.com/) GeoJSON [responses](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/geocoding#responses) data.
    
- Check out the **Body** of the request to access and change the visualization data.
    
- Open the request scripts tab to see how Postman builds the response data into a visualization. Change it to tweak your display!

# Echo visualizer

Requests showing how you can use the Postman Visualizer - by sending the data you want to visualize to the Postman Echo API.

- The [Postman Echo API](https://docs.postman-echo.com/) helps you learn Postman by echoing back whatever you send it.
    
- This template uses a `POST` request with **raw** `JSON` in the **Body** to send the data you want to visualize. Here we are using the [Naurt](https://www.naurt.com/) GeoJSON [responses](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/geocoding#responses) data.
    
- Check out the **Body** of the request to access and change the visualization data.
    
- Open the request scripts tab to see how Postman builds the response data into a visualization. Change it to tweak your display!

item.description: [Postman Visualizer](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/response-data/visualizer/) provides a programmable way to visually represent your request responses. Visualization code added to the scripts for a request will render in the Visualize tab for the response body, alongside the Pretty, Raw, and Preview options. All the above request samples are already equipped with the required scripts to render the vizualization. This folder has a few GeoJson samples that you can try out to see the vizualizer in action. It just uses the postman echo endpoint and the [Naurt](https://www.naurt.com/) GeoJSON [responses](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/geocoding#responses) # Echo visualizer Requests showing how you can use the Postman Visualizer - by sending the data you want to visualize to the Postman Echo API. - The [Postman Echo API](https://docs.postman-echo.com/) helps you learn Postman by echoing back whatever you send it. - This template uses a `POST` request with **raw** `JSON` in the **Body** to send the data you want to visualize. Here we are using the [Naurt](https://www.naurt.com/) GeoJSON [responses](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/geocoding#responses) data. - Check out the **Body** of the request to access and change the visualization data. - Open the request scripts tab to see how Postman builds the response data into a visualization. Change it to tweak your display!

exec: // Check if the response contains the expected data structure
var map = L.map('map').setView([0, 0], 14); // Adjust zoom level for faster initial load

pm.visualizer.set(`

GeoJSON data not available in the response.

`);

item.description: Before you start making requests, you'll need to sign up for a free Naurt account on the [Naurt dashboard](https://dashboard.naurt.com/sign-up). All we require is a verified email and you'll be good to go. On the dashboard, your API key starting with `nk_`, will be found pre-loaded with **4800** requests per calendar month so you can start using Naurt right away. ## [Final Destination endpoint](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/account#final-destination-endpoint) Naurt's final destination data can be accessed through the following endpoint. ``` json https://api.naurt.net/final-destination/v1 ``` ### [Authorization & Content-Type](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/account#authorization-content-type) Every request made to Naurt will need to contain a valid API key. Within a header of the request make sure you include, ``` json Authorization: ``` Naurt also requires every request to have a valid JSON body. In another header, make sure to include, ``` json Content-Type: application/json ``` ### Note For ease of use, you can paste in the API KEY in the Authorization section of this folder (Final Destination) and all the subsequent requests are be set to use the same. The endpoint is also set to [Final Destination endpoint ](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/account#final-destination-endpoint) through the scripts in this folder. So that anyone can try out our collection without worrying about configuring environemnt or keys. So let's get started!. ### **Geojson Vizualizer** [Postman Visualizer](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/response-data/visualizer/) provides a programmable way to visually represent your request responses. Visualization code added to the scripts for a request will render in the Visualize tab for the response body, alongside the Pretty, Raw, and Preview options. Here, we have added the scripts for Postman's Visualizer to display geographic data on a map using Leaflet. We'll transform [Naurt](https://www.naurt.com/) GeoJSON [responses](https://docs.naurt.com/quickstart/geocoding#responses) into interactive maps directly within Postman, providing a powerful way to visualize data.

exec: // Check if the response contains the expected data structure
var map = L.map('map').setView([0, 0], 14); // Adjust zoom level for faster initial load

pm.visualizer.set(`

GeoJSON data not available in the response.

`);
